response.answer_text: Over the years social media has grown to be one of our primary methods of communication[1]. As social media continues to grow and people continue to move their lives onto online database, people are becoming more anti-social. Due to the ease of social media, millions of people have begun to move their interactions and conversations to the online world. For example, instead of catching up with an old friend or colleague in person over lunch, coffee, etc., people will simply text or message each other on social media platforms eliminating face to face interactions[2] . Furthermore, due to constant Facebook and Instagram profile updates, some people feel as if they are already caught up on the lives of their friends and feel no need to personally message them at all making them very anti-social. It seems as though instead of making an effort to verbally reconnect with old friends, people would rather sit at home on their technological devices and learn what their friends are up to through a social media platform. This perfectly illustrates how social media is making many people in our society more anti-social. Secondly, when individuals do chose to hang out or meet up with friends face to face, their conversations are often interrupted or cut short due to social media, thus making them more anti-social[3]. Think about it, have you ever been telling a friend or family member a story only to look up and see them sitting on their phone scrolling through their social media feeds or texting? Sadly, the answer for most people would be yes. When people do choose to hangout or catch up with friends they are no longer present in conversation due to social media and technology[4]. People will partially pay attention to the conversation being held in person while either having a completely separate conversation online through the use of social media or simply by just checking their social media feeds. This results in short conversations that lack the depth, importance, and interest proving that our society is becoming more anti-social. One of the very upsetting parts about this is that the constant use of social media, even when in the middle of a conversation, is becoming more and more widely accepted[5]. This constant interruption of using social media while in the middle of face to face interactions helps lead to the fact that the ability for individuals to have strong, focussed conversations, is slowly weakening at a rapid rate as we become more anti-social due to social media[6]. It has gotten to a point where teenagers will hangout in complete silence for long periods of time while they check their social media feeds, not saying a single word to their peers sitting in the same room. This clearly demonstrates how society is becoming much more anti-social due to social media. People simply need to make a more active effort to get out of their houses and meet up with others face to face to have good conversation and maintain connections rather than turning to social media platforms to do so. When doing so, it is vital that individuals remain present in conversation rather than constantly checking their phones to see updates on their social media platforms. This will help society break free from the anti-social bubble we are beginning to form around ourselves. Not necessarily. I know many people who are active on social media and most of them seem perfectly well-integrated to me. They combine social media with a healthy social life. However, this is just my experience. What I would say is that people have become conditioned to social media - in the sense that everywhere they go - they are virtually glued to their phone. This does strike me as anti-social behavior in that such people have a conditioned dependency - much like drug addicts. Furthermore, one of the perverse side-effects of social media is that it heavily promotes mob mentality - which is inherently anti-social. Because people are inclined to gravitate towards those who share similar opinions and beliefs - this disposition tends to reduce their capacity to think critically. Mob mentality is unfortunately embedded in our DNA. Because human beings are pack creatures who have always existed in small groups (not mass societies) - this was how we survived and still do. Research has shown that moving against the pack provokes the alarm circuits in our brain while conformity keeps us calm. So essentially, it’s easier to fit in rather than stick out. This is where the dreaded phrase “mob mentality” comes from - which describes how people are influenced by their peers to adopt certain behaviors. Mob mentality is fundamentally anti-social and is rampant on social media in particular. Furthermore, neurobiologists have found that when people break off into groups, their brain produces chemicals that diminishes their normal thought pattern to a more primitive state. Which literally means people stop thinking when they’re amalgamated into groups. An extreme example of such mob mentality was highlighted by “Dr Hannah Arendt” who coined the phrase “The banality of evil”. She controversially argues that what happened in Nazi Germany could largely be blamed on ordinary people conforming to mass opinion without a critical evaluation of the consequences of their actions”. The underlying point here is that we need disagreements and debates to sharpen ourselves. Succumbing to conformity quashes growth - thereby creating stagnation in the process which brings upon it a sort of putrid rot. It makes you wonder how many past atrocities could have been averted and future acts of violence - if people thwarted away the herd mentality and started thinking for themselves. In my ideal world, social media wouldn’t exist. Too much knowledge and information is a bad thing; too much circulation of news and gossip is a bad thing; too much of anything is a bad thing when it’s on display for other people to see. Social media only promotes a busybody culture - from which the mob mentality emerges as a consequence. Hope this helps

Social media is indeed making us more anti-social. Our social skills are deteriorating at an increasing rate due to social media. “Skills we use to communicate and interact with each other, both verbally and non-verbally, through gestures, body language and our personal appearance” [1] are not being practiced enough due to the amount of time we dedicate to our gadgets, and specifically social media sites and applications. Due to the lack of face-to-face conversations we now hold, we are not developing the aforementioned social skills that help us connect with each other. “Because smart phones are so convenient, it is very easy for people to get distracted, which does not help our social skills.” [2] All it takes to get on Facebook and other social apps is simply taking out our phones and we are automatically logged into the app of our choice at a touch. The effort of connecting to a dial-up internet modem is no longer a relevant issue. About 30 years ago is when Internet relay chats (IRC) were first used [3]. The main goal of this was to facilitate communication via text. Two individuals would use IRC to communicate with each other when they were away, but if they are meeting in-person, they would prioritize that interaction over any messages that were being received in their IRC. In today’s day and age, social media apps and sites such as Snapchat, Instagram, and Facebook are taking priority over face-to-face interactions. We often see individuals going on their phone to check their social apps while in the presence of other people. While it can be argued that social media makes it easier to organize group chats and plan group activities, if we are too busy showing our friends on snapchat what is happening, the questions arises if we really are enjoying the company of the friends that are currently present. In the absence of social media, we would make the effort to go to our friend/family member’s house and truly enjoy their company. Due to the increasing usership of social media, the emotional intelligence of individuals is decreasing. It is much more difficult to “recognize, understand and influence the emotions of others” [4] over text versus in person. “A recent study, published in the Journal of Organizational Behavior, by Ernest O’Boyle Jr. at Virginia Commonwealth University, concludes that emotional intelligence is the strongest predictor of job performance. Numerous other studies have shown that high emotional intelligence boosts career success.” [5] Therefore, not only is social media making us more anti-social, it can also negatively affect our job performance and professional lives. The Journal of Organizational Behavior by Lillian Eby is a recent study that states that “nearly 3,000 scientific articles have been published on EQ since the concept was first introduced. These studies conclude that while EQ is mostly influenced by our early childhood experiences.” [6] Thus, if we let social media affect us and degrade our emotional intelligence from an early age, it will be very difficult to improve it later on in life. Social media can be seen as both a tool for attempting to maintain existing friendships as well as create new ones based on common interest. This is socially understood to be the main reason (at least that people say) they use much of social media, including platforms such as Facebook, Instagram and newer apps like Shapr. Though, obviously, from a critical perspective there are other reasons for use such as monetization, and general voyeurism. But at the same time, these platforms can be seen as creating a distancing affect that makes people communicate more through media, and less often in real physical space. Social media can actually have an alienating effect of making people see friendships, communicated by itemizations such as followers, likes, friends, etc., that they monitor in comparison to others [1]. Jealousy and feelings of inadequacy stemming from these issues, as well as other related self-consciousness issues from image, distance users’ relationships to each other. Dr. Graham C.L. Davey wrote for Psychology Today about this phenomenon, finding that feelings of loneliness and anxiety were both created from using social media, but paradoxically also drive the need to compulsively use and check it. It is also connected to FOMO (fear of missing out), when taking into account that users feel a need to stay “updated” on each other’s lives, and that they may see events etc. that they were not invited to (ex: someone’s wedding picture on Instagram, Facebook giving you the notification that your friends are attending an event near you tomorrow). Loneliness, though hard to quantify and outright identify, has been seen as steadily increasing in society [2]. Social media continues to market itself as a promising platform for social engagement, but will continue to paradoxically take time away from real relationships. But in terms of specific, smaller forms of social connection, social media can be helpful: invitations to events, sharing pictures with friends and family abroad, and maintaining a way to contact an acquaintance from the past. But there are limits, and dangerous consequences in overuse. It is no wonder Facebook has now mostly become inundated by posts of older generations. Although there are many benefits of social media (connecting with people you care about who live farther away, being able to see what is happening in your location), there are elements of social media that have the potential to make us more antisocial. Suler (2004) wrote about the disinhibition effect. There are six factors that can influence behavior online. I will only describe four because I think they are more relevant for antisocial behavior. Dissociative anonymity: when people’s real identity is covered up by an email or username, there’s less of a perceived risk of consequences for their online actions. People may become more likely to open up about their lives and express themselves more readily than they would if their boss or family could see what they were saying.Invisibility: being invisible in cyberspace gives people courage to do things they wouldn’t normally do because no one can see them. This is particularly true of text-driven environments such as chatrooms or forums. This invisibility makes the disinhibition stronger because the actor won’t see the judgmental faces of others and the other won’t see how the actor is feeling as they are disclosing information or passing judgment.Asynchronicity: In real life, interactions with others are synchronous or happening at the same time. In contrast, people online can choose when they want to respond (in the same moment, days or weeks after the initial interaction). This disinhibits people’s reactions, and online psychotherapist K. Munro (2003) says that there may be cases of “emotional hit and run”, where someone may leave a hostile or personal message and leave it behind. It’s probably harder to insult someone in person because you have to see their feelings get hurt, but online you can opt-out.Minimization of status and authority: online, people have a relatively equal opportunity to state their opinion. In real life, an authority figure’s status is known and your actions will have consequences (legally, socially, at work). The fear of being punished offline is greatly reduced when you go online - therefore, youre more likely to misbehave.I recommend reading the entire paper and having a look around for more literature. It’s very interesting, and can tell you more about the motivations behind antisocial behavior online.

This is an interesting topic. ‘Social Media’ and ‘Anti-social’ nearly act as antonym’s, yet a common topic of discussion nowadays revolves around the proposition that platforms meant to engage our society in collaborative discussion (Social Media), actually cause distance and segregation. I assume the use of ‘anti-social’ presumes that humans aren’t communicating offline as frequently as they once did. Personally, I believe that Humans aren’t unwilling to communicate, however, how we communicate has changed drastically. Nonetheless, Research has stated that though Social Media usage has not been directly linked to increases in ‘anti-social’ behavior, it has shown correlations between people who use social media more often and those user’s likelihood to report feeling socially isolated[i]. Specifically, “people who spent more time on social media—two hours a day or more—had twice the odds of feeling socially isolated than people who spent less than half an hour a day on it”[ii]. However, Elizabeth Miller of the University of Pittsburgh stated, “We do not yet know which came first—the social media use or the perceived social isolation”[iii]. This leads us to conclude that we cannot make any assumptions as to whether Social Media explicitly causes ‘anti-social’ behaviors. We can only speculate. The same study delved into possible reasons for feelings of social isolation. A largely theorized cause accredits people’s behavioral tendency to compare themselves to other people. Comparing yourself to others on Social Media is not new to anyone, and can illicit a stronger psychological effect than most realize. Social Comparison is a widely used term and concept in consumer behavior and marketing strategy. The term refers to consumer’s tendency to compare themselves to the people they surround themselves with. Marketer’s use this concept to tailor and customize products/advertisements to satisfy consumers need for achievement. Why is this important? I want to emphasize that Social Comparison occurs in the absence of Social Media. However, Social media platforms can empower, and even justify Social Comparison. Ego padding, group coercion, self validation/gratification and echo chambers all existed prior to Social Media. Let's not pretend that Social Media is the problem; it's just an enabler. I do not believe that Social Media is making us ‘anti-social’, per se. Humans are more interconnected than ever before. Globalization of commerce was the tip of the iceberg. Now we experience the globalization of culture, communication, and interaction. I do, however, believe that a consequence of such interconnectedness is the expedited transcendence of pre-existing psychological phenomena. As I said before, issues like Social Comparison existed long before Social Media did. Social Media has simply made it easier for us to compare ourselves. In turn, humans will experience the negative effects at a larger and more prevalent rate. The use of social media has proliferated within the last decade or so. About 80% of Americans claim they have a social media profile; 94% of teenagers check their social media accounts daily. You would assume that this helps us stay connected with one another on a more intimate level. Unfortunately that’s not the case. Think about all those times when you were in an awkward situation. What’s you first reaction? You whip out your phone from your pocket and randomly start scrolling down through your contacts or checking aimlessly for notifications. Whether you’re in a elevator, in a meeting, or even in a pub, you can’t stand sitting next to a random person in fear of him or her initiating an uncomfortable conversation. By being on your phone, you’re sending the body signal that you’re busy and preoccupied at the moment with your device. Even if you aren’t doing anything important, others assume you don’t want to be talked to. Even in social events, people try to avoid talking to people that are on their phones. The thing with social media is it’s fake. You can portray this false image of yourself and nobody would take a second glance. It’s essentially a contest to see who’s living the best life. In effect, people start comparing their lives to others and become depressed when they see their accomplishments aren’t meeting the expectations of others. Also, I feel like when people are always posting updates about their lives, there’s nothing to talk about it when they each other since they’ve already informed the whole world. How a Conversation Would Go Between Teenagers Nowadays “Hey what did you do last weekend?” “Didn’t you check my Instagram stories? I posted everything on there.” “Oh yeah….”(awkward pause desperately trying to figure out what to say next.) Of course there are some positive aspects about social media. Such as keeping long-distance relationships and spreading awareness on vital issues, or even advertising new businesses. In the end, it’s essentially what you make out of it. But we can unanimously agree social media is not a confidence booster and definitely not increasing our social intelligence.

There are two problems with social media interactions. It is making some of us more asocial. As in: Reducing the occurrence of physical social contacts and thus reducing the need for, and thereby causing a lack of social skills for face to face contacts.It is making some of us (a lot of us, it seems) more antisocial. We “say” things to other people on social media that we would never say to them in person. We are rude and all too often feel free to leave snarky and hateful comments on posts and topics, because we feel safely anonymous. Many people have been burned by this false sense of anonymity, especially politicians and employees everywhere.I speak from experience. I’m an introvert and I love interacting in a written format, it gives me time to think and formulate my thoughts much better. I’m awkward and uncomfortable in social situations, and also bored, because I don’t enjoy the small talk. I am usually a kind and thoughtful person, but I find myself leaving witty and snarky comments on other peoples’ posts to amuse myself and to dazzle the world with my wit. I have observed other people whom I know, to be a different kind of person when I see their comments on Facebook or wherever. I have one person in mind whom I know quite well to be a very thoughtful, kind, and intelligent man when face to face, be a complete troll online. I have noticed it, and I’m trying to stop it, but the perceived anonymity makes it very tempting!

There is a notion that social media, although labelled as a social platform, is making us increasingly anti-social, however, the accuracy of this statement depends on how you define social. There is an undeniable act of socializing on social media - it just consists of a different kind of socializing. Social media allows us to communicate with a larger group of people at once, and it should not be completely considered anti-social. It is not a question of becoming anti-social, but a change in the definition of social. In a way social media allows us to interact with people who share our interests and whom we may not have met without access to social media. In a Huffington Post article, Molly Reynolds writes that, ‘Because of social media, we are able to connect with people that we would never have the opportunity to meet, simply because we are allowed access — instead of having to be in the right place at the right time.’ [1] Social media is allowing us to meet people and therefore making us increasingly social in this sense. Although friendships may exist purely online, they may also develop into offline relationships that started thanks to the ability of social media to connect us with like-minded individuals. In an instance where someone may not be surrounded by like-minded people, social media may in fact serve as a social escape from one’s isolation. Isolation can occur when someone is not surrounded by people with which they feel comfortable, and therefore, they may not want to partake in social activities. In these cases, social media may act as a social outlet for individuals to connect with people that share their interests and give them a place to socialize. When radio and television were introduced, there was a fear that these new technologies would make us anti-social, but instead they have become integrated into our social habits. Quora is a positive exception: I can ask whatever I want, people can answer whatever they want, we all get an unfiltered sample of opinions we are free to average.
